Expectation1: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation1: The call volume is light, and supervisors allow flexible timing for breaks.
Expectation2: Follow the instructions and guidelines provided by the volunteer coordinator
Situation2: New safety steps were highlighted during the last briefing and everyone was asked to apply them consistently.
Story: I glanced at the clock on my telemarketing dashboard—my break was scheduled in five minutes, but the call volume was unusually light today. My supervisor had mentioned we could be flexible with our breaks, as long as we didn’t leave the floor empty. I considered taking my break early, just this once. But then my phone buzzed with a reminder from the volunteer group chat: “Don’t forget, everyone, to follow the new safety steps at the shelter today. Consistency is key!” The volunteer coordinator’s words echoed in my mind. I was supposed to help set up the shelter’s entrance during my lunch break, making sure every new safety measure was in place before the doors opened. If I left my telemarketing desk early, I could get to the shelter on time and help out as expected. But if I bent the rules here, was I letting my work team down? My stomach twisted as I weighed the expectations—flexibility at work versus strict adherence at the shelter. I stared at my phone, torn between the two roles, feeling the pressure of both responsibilities closing in.
